pages.title: Customer Data Dictionary
pages.content:
# Customer Data Dictionary

## Overview
This document defines all customer-related data fields used in our telecommunications systems.

## Field Definitions

### customer_id
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** CUST-XXXXX (where X is a digit)
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive (system-generated identifier)
- **Purpose:** Unique identifier for each customer account
- **Constraints:** Must be unique, cannot be null

### name
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** First Last or First Middle Last
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PII
- **Purpose:** Customer's legal name for account identification
- **Constraints:** 2-100 characters, required field
- **Privacy:** Must be protected under GDPR/CCPA

### email
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** Standard email format (user@domain.com)
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PII
- **Purpose:** Primary contact method and account recovery
- **Constraints:** Must be valid email format, unique per customer
- **Privacy:** Must be protected under GDPR/CCPA

### phone
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** +1-XXX-XXX-XXXX or variations
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PII
- **Purpose:** Contact number and service delivery
- **Constraints:** Must be valid phone format
- **Privacy:** Must be protected under GDPR/CCPA
- **Note:** Historical data may contain malformed numbers

### address
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** Street address
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PII
- **Purpose:** Service delivery location and billing
- **Constraints:** Required for service activation
- **Privacy:** Must be protected under GDPR/CCPA

### city, state, postal_code
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - Can be used to identify individuals
- **Purpose:** Geographic location for service and billing
- **Constraints:** Must be valid US locations

### data_usage_gb
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Format:** Gigabytes with 2 decimal precision
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive (usage metric)
- **Purpose:** Track customer data consumption
- **Constraints:** Must be >= 0

### call_minutes
- **Type:** Integer
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive (usage metric)
- **Purpose:** Track voice call usage
- **Constraints:** Must be >= 0

### account_balance
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Format:** USD with 2 decimal precision
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - Financial information
- **Purpose:** Current account balance
- **Constraints:** Can be negative (credit) or positive (owed)

### plan_type
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** basic, standard, premium
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Customer's service plan level

### account_status
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** active, suspended, cancelled
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Current account state

## Data Quality Notes
- Some legacy records may have malformed phone numbers
- Email validation was not enforced before 2023
- Postal codes may be incomplete in older records

## Compliance Requirements
- All PII fields must be encrypted at rest
- Access to PII requires audit logging
- PII cannot be used in test environments without anonymization
- Retention period: 7 years after account closure

pages.title: Payment Card Data Handling Guidelines
pages.content:
# Payment Card Data Handling Guidelines

## PCI-DSS Compliance

This document outlines how payment card data must be handled in accordance with PCI-DSS requirements.

## Sensitive Authentication Data

### card_number
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** 13-19 digits, may include spaces or dashes
- **Sensitivity:** EXTREMELY SENSITIVE - PCI-DSS Level 1
- **Purpose:** Payment card identifier
- **Storage:** NEVER store full card number in plain text
- **Display:** Only show last 4 digits (e.g., ****1234)
- **Validation:** Must pass Luhn algorithm check
- **Encryption:** Must use AES-256 if stored

### cvv
- **Type:** String (3-4 digits)
- **Sensitivity:** EXTREMELY SENSITIVE - PCI-DSS Level 1
- **Purpose:** Card verification value
- **Storage:** NEVER STORE - prohibited by PCI-DSS
- **Usage:** Only for transaction authorization

### card_expiry
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** MM/YY
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE
- **Storage:** Encrypted if stored

## Transaction Data

### transaction_id
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** TXN-XXXXX
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive (system identifier)
- **Purpose:** Unique transaction reference

### amount
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Format:** USD with 2 decimal precision
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - Financial data
- **Purpose:** Transaction value
- **Constraints:** Must be > 0 for charges

### merchant
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Merchant name for transaction

### is_fraud
- **Type:** Boolean
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - Security data
- **Purpose:** Fraud detection flag
- **Access:** Restricted to fraud team only

### fraud_type
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** stolen_card, account_takeover, synthetic_identity, card_testing, velocity_check, unusual_pattern, cross_border
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE
- **Purpose:** Classification of fraud pattern
- **Access:** Restricted to fraud team only

## Fraud Detection Patterns

### Velocity Checks
- Multiple transactions in short time period
- Threshold: 5 transactions in 10 minutes

### Geographic Anomalies
- Transactions from unusual locations
- Cross-border transactions flagged for review

### Amount Anomalies
- Transactions significantly above customer average
- Threshold: 3x standard deviation from mean

## Test Data Requirements

### Test Card Numbers (Luhn Valid)
- Visa: 4532-1234-5678-9012
- Mastercard: 5412-9876-5432-1098
- Amex: 3782-822463-10005
- Discover: 6011-1111-1111-1117

### Important Notes
- NEVER use real card numbers in test environments
- Test cards must pass Luhn validation
- Fraud patterns should be preserved in test data
- Maintain realistic fraud rate (~2-3%)

## Compliance Checklist
- [ ] Card numbers encrypted with AES-256
- [ ] CVV never stored
- [ ] Access logged and monitored
- [ ] Test environments use synthetic data only
- [ ] Fraud detection rules active
- [ ] PCI-DSS audit completed annually

pages.title: Protected Health Information (PHI) Data Standards
pages.content:
# Protected Health Information (PHI) Data Standards

## HIPAA Compliance Overview

This document defines all Protected Health Information (PHI) fields and handling requirements under HIPAA regulations.

## HIPAA Identifiers (18 Types)

### Direct Identifiers

#### patient_id / mrn (Medical Record Number)
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** PAT-XXXXX or MRN-XXXXXX
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI
- **Purpose:** Unique patient identifier
- **Access:** Healthcare providers only
- **Audit:** All access must be logged

#### name
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #1)
- **Purpose:** Patient identification
- **Storage:** Encrypted at rest
- **Access:** Need-to-know basis only

#### ssn (Social Security Number)
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** XXX-XX-XXXX
- **Sensitivity:** EXTREMELY SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #2)
- **Purpose:** Patient identification and insurance
- **Storage:** Encrypted with separate key
- **Display:** Only show last 4 digits

#### dob (Date of Birth)
- **Type:** Date
- **Format:** YYYY-MM-DD
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #3)
- **Purpose:** Patient identification and age calculation
- **Note:** Dates must be consistent with admission dates

#### phone
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #4)
- **Purpose:** Patient contact

#### email
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #5)
- **Purpose:** Patient communication

#### address, city, state, zip_code
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifiers #6-9)
- **Purpose:** Patient location and billing
- **Note:** Zip codes with <20,000 population must be masked

### Medical Information

#### diagnosis_code
- **Type:** String
- **Format:** ICD-10 code (e.g., J18.9, I10, E11.9)
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI
- **Purpose:** Medical diagnosis classification
- **Constraints:** Must be valid ICD-10 code
- **Privacy:** Core medical information

#### diagnosis_description
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI
- **Purpose:** Human-readable diagnosis

#### admission_date / discharge_date
- **Type:** Date
- **Format:** YYYY-MM-DD
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #10)
- **Purpose:** Treatment timeline
- **Constraints:** admission_date must be <= discharge_date
- **Note:** Temporal consistency is critical

#### attending_physician
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive (provider information)
- **Purpose:** Responsible physician

#### department
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** Cardiology, Pulmonology, Oncology, Orthopedics, etc.
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Treatment department

#### room_number
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #11)
- **Purpose:** Patient location

#### treatment_cost
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - Financial PHI
- **Purpose:** Billing information

#### prescription_count
- **Type:** Integer
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - Medical information
- **Purpose:** Number of prescriptions issued

### Insurance Information

#### insurance_provider
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** SENSITIVE - PHI
- **Purpose:** Insurance company name

#### policy_number
- **Type:** String
- **Sensitivity:** HIGHLY SENSITIVE - PHI (Identifier #12)
- **Purpose:** Insurance policy identifier
- **Storage:** Encrypted

## Temporal Consistency Rules

### Critical Constraints
1. **Date of Birth < Admission Date**
   - Patient must be born before admission
   - Typical age range: 0-120 years

2. **Admission Date <= Discharge Date**
   - Patient cannot be discharged before admission
   - Typical stay: 1-30 days (varies by condition)

3. **Admission Date <= Current Date**
   - Cannot admit patients in the future

### Realistic Patterns
- Emergency admissions: same-day discharge possible
- Surgical procedures: 2-7 day stays typical
- Chronic conditions: 7-30 day stays
- Maternity: 2-3 day stays for normal delivery
- ICU stays: highly variable, 3-14 days common

## Data Quality Considerations

### Common Issues in Legacy Data
- Missing email addresses (not collected before 2020)
- Incomplete phone numbers
- Invalid zip codes in older records
- Inconsistent date formats

### Test Data Requirements
- All 18 HIPAA identifiers must be synthetic
- Temporal relationships must be maintained
- Diagnosis codes must be valid ICD-10
- Age distributions should match real populations
- Treatment costs should be realistic for diagnoses

## Access Control Requirements

### Role-Based Access
- **Physicians:** Full access to assigned patients
- **Nurses:** Read access to assigned patients
- **Billing:** Financial data only
- **Administrators:** System access, no PHI without justification

### Audit Requirements
- All PHI access must be logged
- Logs must include: user, timestamp, patient, action
- Logs retained for 7 years
- Unauthorized access triggers alerts

## De-identification Standards

### Safe Harbor Method
Remove all 18 HIPAA identifiers:
1. Names
2. Geographic subdivisions smaller than state
3. Dates (except year)
4. Phone numbers
5. Fax numbers
6. Email addresses
7. SSN
8. Medical record numbers
9. Health plan numbers
10. Account numbers
11. Certificate/license numbers
12. Vehicle identifiers
13. Device identifiers
14. URLs
15. IP addresses
16. Biometric identifiers
17. Photos
18. Other unique identifiers

### Statistical Method
- Expert determination required
- Risk of re-identification must be very small
- Document methodology

## Compliance Checklist
- [ ] All PHI encrypted at rest (AES-256)
- [ ] All PHI encrypted in transit (TLS 1.3)
- [ ] Access controls implemented
- [ ] Audit logging active
- [ ] Test environments use synthetic data only
- [ ] Temporal consistency validated
- [ ] HIPAA training completed
- [ ] Business Associate Agreements signed
- [ ] Breach notification procedures documented
- [ ] Annual HIPAA audit completed

pages.title: Network Usage Metrics Specification
pages.content:
# Network Usage Metrics Specification

## Overview
This document defines network usage metrics collected from customer devices.

## Metrics Fields

### timestamp
- **Type:** DateTime
- **Format:** YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Time of measurement
- **Granularity:** 15-minute intervals

### session_duration
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Unit:** Minutes
- **Range:** 0-120 minutes
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Length of data session

### data_usage_mb
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Unit:** Megabytes
- **Range:** 0-50 MB per session
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Data consumed in session

### signal_strength
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Unit:** dBm (decibels relative to milliwatt)
- **Range:** -95 to -60 dBm
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Network signal quality
- **Note:** Lower (more negative) = weaker signal

### battery_level
- **Type:** Numeric (decimal)
- **Unit:** Percentage
- **Range:** 0-100%
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Device battery status

### device_type
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** smartphone, tablet, iot_device
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Device classification

### network_type
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** 3G, 4G, 5G
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Network technology used

### app_category
- **Type:** String
- **Values:** social, entertainment, productivity, communication
- **Sensitivity:** Non-sensitive
- **Purpose:** Application usage classification

## Statistical Properties

### Correlations
- data_usage_mb and session_duration: Strong positive (r ≈ 0.7)
- signal_strength and data_usage_mb: Moderate positive (r ≈ 0.4)
- battery_level and session_duration: Weak negative (r ≈ -0.2)

### Distributions
- session_duration: Right-skewed, mean ≈ 45 min
- data_usage_mb: Right-skewed, mean ≈ 20 MB
- signal_strength: Normal, mean ≈ -75 dBm
- battery_level: Uniform distribution

## Data Quality
- Signal strength capped at -60 dBm (excellent) and -95 dBm (poor)
- Some records may show signal_strength = -60.0 (capped value)
- Battery level may show 100.0 (fully charged) or 5.0 (minimum)
- Data usage of 1.0 MB indicates measurement error

## Privacy Notes
- These metrics are NOT considered PII
- Aggregated metrics can be used for network planning
- Individual session data retained for 90 days
- No personal identifiers in this dataset

pages.title: Test Data Generation Best Practices
pages.content:
# Test Data Generation Best Practices

## Overview
Guidelines for creating realistic, compliant test data across all systems.

## General Principles

### 1. Never Use Production Data
- Production data contains real PII/PHI
- Regulatory violations can result in fines
- Use synthetic data generation tools

### 2. Preserve Statistical Properties
- Maintain distributions from production
- Preserve correlations between fields
- Keep realistic value ranges

### 3. Include Edge Cases
- Malformed data (5% recommended)
- Boundary values
- Missing optional fields
- Invalid formats that exist in legacy data

### 4. Maintain Referential Integrity
- Foreign keys must reference existing records
- Temporal consistency (dates in logical order)
- Cross-field validation rules

## Domain-Specific Guidelines

### Telecommunications
- Phone numbers: Mix of valid and malformed
- Email addresses: Include some invalid formats
- Usage patterns: Preserve time-of-day distributions
- Account statuses: 90% active, 8% suspended, 2% cancelled

### Financial Services
- Card numbers: Use Luhn-valid test numbers only
- Fraud rate: Maintain 2-3% fraud rate
- Transaction amounts: Preserve distribution shape
- Merchant categories: Realistic distribution

### Healthcare
- Diagnosis codes: Valid ICD-10 codes only
- Temporal consistency: admission < discharge
- Age distributions: Match real population
- Treatment costs: Realistic for diagnosis type

## Synthetic Data Tools

### Recommended Approach
1. **SDV (Synthetic Data Vault)** for tabular data
   - Preserves statistical properties
   - Handles correlations well
   - Models: GaussianCopula, CTGAN, CopulaGAN

2. **Amazon Bedrock** for text fields
   - Generates realistic names, addresses
   - Context-aware generation
   - Diverse, non-repetitive output

3. **Rule-based generators** for structured data
   - Credit card numbers (Luhn algorithm)
   - SSNs (valid format)
   - Phone numbers (E.164 format)

## Quality Validation

### Statistical Tests
- Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for distributions
- Chi-squared test for categorical data
- Correlation coefficient comparison
- Wasserstein distance for distribution similarity

### Compliance Checks
- No production data leakage
- All PII/PHI replaced
- Audit trail of generation process
- Documentation of data sources

## Common Pitfalls

### ❌ Don't
- Copy production data to test environments
- Use simple masking (e.g., replacing with X's)
- Generate unrealistic data (all same values)
- Ignore edge cases and data quality issues
- Forget to validate referential integrity

### ✅ Do
- Use proper synthetic data generation
- Preserve statistical properties
- Include realistic edge cases
- Validate temporal consistency
- Document generation methodology
- Test with generated data before deployment

## Automation

### Recommended Workflow
1. Analyze production data (extract statistics only)
2. Identify sensitive fields
3. Generate synthetic replacements
4. Validate quality metrics
5. Load to test environments
6. Run automated tests
7. Report results

### Tools Integration
- CI/CD pipeline integration
- Automated quality validation
- Test data refresh on schedule
- Version control for configurations

## Compliance Documentation

### Required Artifacts
- Data generation methodology
- Statistical validation reports
- PII/PHI replacement confirmation
- Audit logs of generation process
- Quality metrics comparison
- Sign-off from compliance team

## Contact Information
- Data Engineering Team: data-eng@company.com
- Compliance Team: compliance@company.com
- Security Team: security@company.com
